topic.title: stupid question
topic.body: so I saw that zeronet uses blockchains, like bitcoin.  does that mean i can make money using zeronet?

topic.title: zeronet is a good start
topic.body:
but it's only the first step to a decentralized internet.

i refer you to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OSI_model#Description_of_OSI_layers

zeronet does an excellent job of decentralizing layers 5-7, but the isps still control layers 4 and below.  And that presents a problem, in that while anyone can host a site, anyone trying to download it has to go through the centralized isps at some point.  and that means that an isp can block any data relating to a zeronet site, or worst case, zeronet as a whole.

what we need to do is completely reinvent networking.  everyone needs to be their own isp.  i am aware that there are obstacles, and i'm still trying to figure this all out myself.

it'd be a great topic for zerocon, but i can't afford to travel to europe atm.  i will update when i have more.

1_1PiXrhT1UjMZmJc5WFhfUxourdfapeHJ8o.body:
> [cosmologica](#comment_16_1PiXrhT1UjMZmJc5WFhfUxourdfapeHJ8o): The hooktube for the youtube: https://hooktube.com/watch?v=UUAylWYqzac

Hooktube is great!!! any other sites I should know about?

> [conobs](#comment_1_1AjJqGb8AmPfgD62kEBBtqhg2hYDW5zner): Diaspora (decentralized social network)https://diasporafoundation.org/

the problem with sites like diaspora or minds.com is that they're not really decentralized.  What they do is say "okay, you can use our social media platform on its popular centralized server and pray that we don't censor you, or you can take our code and use it elsewhere and hope that other people will join you.  This is why I chose Zeronet, because it is the only way to truly decentralize.  Yes, sites like ZeroTalk and ZeroSites can be censored by nofish, but you have the resources to make your own site/blog/whatever without fear of it being taken down (even if links to it are.)

> [james007](#comment_3_1DiRWRFXcVgQQ75cXnAG2pyxxjGo2VaH5): Pretty sure you mean Amazon. They're quickly growing to be much more powerful than Google. [...]

not if we have anything to say about it.

We know that somehow, the key ingredients of the clearnet have been colluding to gather mass intelligence and censor content at will.  That means the future for the internet, the only future with any hope of freedom, is decentralization.  Fortunately, the key ingredients already exist.  However, the task now is to get them to work together.
We all have the same vision: an Internet that CANNOT be censored, lest future generations repeat Google and Facebook's mistakes.  Now we need to work together to make it happen, and we need to do it NOW, before it goes too far.  Otherwise, our children and their children will not know the freedoms we had.

> [cosmologica](#comment_19_1PiXrhT1UjMZmJc5WFhfUxourdfapeHJ8o): An internet that cannot be censored. Would that mean the end of government itself??? An entity where there is no government or government control? Interesting thought. The end of government.

no, governments will still exist.  There were governments before the internet, certainly even the governments of today predate the internet by decades, if not centuries.  What it would end is government censorship, which was never the intent of america's founding fathers.

> [cosmologica](#comment_20_1PiXrhT1UjMZmJc5WFhfUxourdfapeHJ8o): Just dreaming [obiwanzanobi] :-)

"without government, man would eat his fellow alive"

-unknown

3_1JTtwMPZ5mKaF6S1wAPzZ8SmZTgTygz5Rb.body:
13. automatic site change log (a la wikipedia)
14. integrated search engine that auto logs sites and can't be messed with (unlike a certain search engine that starts with a g, ends with an e, has an o and an l in the middle, and censors results like north korea censors journalists
15. run over mesh network (in the near future)
16. supports larger zites and media (think LBRY)
17. easier to make/clone zites and/or zite templates

My friend says that we could, in theory, create this kind of thing using open web technologies. It seems like electron + react could work for the UI, and we may be able to leverage the version of the EVM written in JavaScript as well.

> [kaffie](#comment_500_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Because it's impossible to seize a zeronet site in the manner that was shown. AFAIK the image was from the original silkroad takedown, and the gov's new takedown messages have changed. That particular image has circulated as a joke. It's almost impossible, and is impossible, to find who originally uploaded a site; let alone manage to get their private key and remove the content. Zites that contained the image were originally uploaded well before ZeroNet had any popularity, and well before any illegal activity had taken place. Even now, the gov/feds are likely not here.

then explain to me why the example link below gives me the Site:1FqhRo..4N4w Content.json not exist: data/1FqhRosMouo37Z8iDpLTEPvfznBq1b4N4w/content.json

1512252928_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGN.body:
> [kopyjane](#comment_78_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE): Me and my friend are trying to come up with a good hack, although I'm pretty short on ideas. It can't just be a PC-bricking hack.. it has to be something useful, something that can gather data silently. We can already get these folks to click on links and reveal their IPs. It makes sense, too - if they're calling you, if they're desperate.. you can get them to do anything, really. I almost got a lady to install one of my Add Ons.. although she said that the browser requested permission, probably because it wasn't her PC.

what would you do with the information you got?

also, I bet if you did write a bricking virus, the calls might slow down.
